thesis.description: Phagocytosis stimulates respiration, 'shunt' metabolism of glucose, lactic acid production and formate oxidation by the leucocytes. The stimulation of shunt metabolism of glucose during phagocytosis occurs only aerobically. Glycolytic inhibitors strongly inhibit phagocytosis. Cyanide and azide have no effect on the stimulated respiration and glucose oxidation, however, they completely inhibit the stimulated formate oxidation. Fatty acids with carbon chains from C6 to C15 inhibit phagocytosis.
thesis.creator: Islam, Muhammad. F.
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: Biochemical aspects of phagocytosis.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In a heat exchanger the rate of heat flow from the hot to the cold fluid is proportional to the temperature difference between the two. For design purposes it is essential to know the mean difference in temperature between the inlet and exit temperatures.
thesis.creator: Iqbal, Muhammad.
thesis.subject: Mechanical Engineering.
thesis.title: Thermal effectiveness of a split-flow heat exchanger.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: One characteristic feature of higher plants is their ability to synthesize phenolic compounds in great variety and quantity. Lignin, which constitutes 20-30 % of the dry weight of plants, is formed of phenolic polymers. Phenolic compounds appear to be metabolically inert substances and are considered to be stable and characteristic end products in living plant tissues. No general function can be ascribed to these compounds and no explanation bas been given to their extraordinary diversity. This is possibly one of the reasons why little attention has been given to them by plant physiologists and biochemists in the past.
thesis.creator: Ibrahim, Ragai. K.
thesis.subject: Botany.
thesis.title: Biosynthesis of some phenolic acids and lactones in higher plants using carbon-14.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: It is found possible that an analogue computer be adapted to work on sampled Data and the First Derivative of a Time Function be approximated by a Mathematical Operation using Finite Differencing techniques. A typical Mathematical Operation of the most general possible form is analysed into a set of basic Mathematical Operations each of which is responsible for some of the usually desired features in the approximation. This allows the production of a Mathematical Operation for different approximations with different requirements.
thesis.creator: Hung, Henry. H-L.
thesis.subject: Electrical Engineering.
thesis.title: A sampled-data differentiation scheme on the analogue computer.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A detailed analysis of the phenomenon of whirling and the application of steady-state theory to transient conditions. The equations of mot ion for a simple rotor system subjected to uniform acceleration are set up and a method of solution demonstrated. These solutions are shown to be applicable to the case of simply supported, accelerating, vertical, slender shafts. The theoretical results are found to be in satisfactory agreement with those obtained experimentally and provide a qualitative guide, not only to the effect of angular acceleration, but also to the relative influences of shaft balance, mass, stiffness, and viscous damping upon amplitudes of whirl.
thesis.creator: Howitt, Francis.
thesis.subject: Mechanical Engineering.
thesis.title: The influence of angular acceleration through critical speeds on amplitudes of whirl of a rotating shaft.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: It is normal practice for civil engineers designing steel beams and columns to assume that the joints are free to rotate, unless they are especially designed as "fixed" joints, in which case it is assumed rotation is completely prevented. In actual fact, however, the joints are semi-rigid. Some rotation does take place, but this rotation is resisted by the joint and creates bending moment at the ends of the beam. The relationship between the joint rotation and bending moment cannot, as yet, be determined theoretically.
thesis.creator: Howe, John. W.
thesis.subject: Civil Engineering and Applied Mechanics.
thesis.title: Moment-rotation characteristics of semi-rigid high tensile bolted connections – II.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Each and every employee in France and the Province of Quebec is deemed by law to have an individual labour contract with his employer. The employee may not be aware of this since, in an increasingly large number of cases, the terms and conditions under which he works are created by a collective labour agreement. Nevertheless, such a contract exists, and, in the absence of a collective labour agreement, is the sole source of his obligation to provide the employer with work, and of the employer's obligation to pay him a given salary.
thesis.creator: Hartt, Stanley. H.
thesis.subject: Economics.
thesis.title: The role of the state in employer-employee relations – a comparison of France and the province of Quebec.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A statistical problem falls under the heading of hypothesis testing when there are only two decisions which can be made at the completion of an experiment; the decisions are whether the probability measure of the experiment is in a subset of a class of measures omega, or whether it is in the complement of that subset.
thesis.creator: Harrow, Martin.
thesis.subject: Mathematics.
thesis.title: A survey of some nonparametric tests.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The extracted beam of the cyclotron was modified to give a higher intensity of 1.31 x 10^-10 amps. It had an energy of 90.6 Mev with a full width at half maximum of 1.2 Mev. This was used to investigate Bi209 (p, xn) Po^(210-xn) reactions which produced short-lived isomeric states in Po. Two new isomers were discovered in Po^207 and a new gamma–ray was discovered in the decay of a previously known isomer in Po^205. A search in the energy range from 90 - 10 Mev, and in the time range from 10^-5 sec to 10^-1 sec was made with no other decays observed.
thesis.creator: Hargrove, Clifford. K.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: Short-lived isomeric states of polonium.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: When animals, including man, survive a bacterial infection, they generally become resistant to a second attack of the same pathogenic material. The serum of such individuals is capable of agglutinating or dissolving the bacteria or rendering them susceptible to phagocytosis. These reactions show a high degree of specificity: the serum reacts only with those micro-organisms whose previous invasion has been overcome. The active factor of the serum is referred to as antibody and the bacterium or its components which have elicited the production of the former is called an antigen.
thesis.creator: Gyenes, Ladislas.
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: Isolation and characterization of precipitating and non-precipitating antibodies.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The subject of the legal status of the aircraft commander is to a large extent regulated by all national legal systems. A number reasons have led authorities in each country to legislate on aviation on military grounds as well as for safety reasons. All this, in turn, has given rise to a bewildering variety of rules on the subject. The aircraft commander is essentially destined to act beyond national boundaries and thus under different jurisdictions. Needless to say, this situation causes great concern since the powers and duties of the commander are bound to change according to the provisions of each national legal system.
thesis.creator: Guerreri, Giuseppe.
thesis.subject: Air and Space Law.
thesis.title: The status of the aircraft commander in Italian and international law.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Some innocuaus substances widespread in nature, auch as grass pollen, ragweed pollen, tree pollen, have been shown to have obnoxious and debilitating ettects on Kan. This fact was recognized as long ago as the second century, when Galen recorded that some individuals reacted to the presence of roses in the environment.[...]
thesis.creator: Griffiths, Bertram. W.
thesis.subject: Ragweed
Allergens
thesis.title: The allergens of the dialyzable fraction of ragweed pollen.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: For many years Legg-Calvé-Perthes’ disease has been, and still is, an outstanding problem in the field of orthopaedic surgery because of the discomfort, mental anguish and prolonged convalescence it imposes. It is a problem also because of pain, deformity and disability which it frequently produces during early or middle adult life. Although considerable has been written on Legg-Calvé-Perthes’ disease, very little has been done to investigate the possible etiological factors which may initiate it.
thesis.creator: Greenlaw, Robert. K.
thesis.subject: Experimental Surgery.
thesis.title: Experimental studies on legg-calve-perthes disease.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The reactions between antigens and antibodies constitute the essential basis of all immunological phenomena. Antibodies are proteins formed in-vivo in response to antigenic stimulation. The parameter of antigenicity, i.e., the capacity to induce antibody formation, has been found to be associated with almost all proteins thus far examined and with some lipoproteins and polysaccharides (1). In order to function as an antigen it appears that a substance must have macromolecular dimension and be recognized (by some mechanism as yet unknown) as foreign to the antibody-forming system of cells of the host (2).
thesis.creator: Goodfriend, Lawrence.
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: Antigenicity of estrone-protein conjugates.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The term central depressant is used to cover those centrally acting drugs which can be used to produce general anaesthesia, to induce sleep, to diminish pain, to prevent or mollify seizures, or to diminish or abolish excessive sensation; in short to diminish some aspect of central nervous function, normal or abnormal. Even among those drugs which have in general the same sequence of effects upon the nervous system, the chemical constitution gives no immediate clue as to a possible common mode of action.
thesis.creator: Gonda, Otto.
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: Effects of central depressants and metabolic inhibitors on cerebral glucose-amino acid interrelations.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The spin and rotation of single rigid discs suspended in a liquid undergoing Couette flow and the translational and rotational motions of single suspended rigid spheres, rods and discs as well as the deformation of fluid drops in Poiseuille flow have been studied. With the exception of wall effects in Poiseuille flow quantitative agreement with theories due to Jeffery and Taylor were obtained. The existence of axial migration with fluid drops and its absence with rigid particles in Poiseuille flow was demonstrated and good agreement with an approximate theory found.
thesis.creator: Goldsmith, Harry. L.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The microrheology of suspensions.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The mechanisms controlling erythropoiesis have posed a fascinating problem for almost a century. In dealing with this problem, experimentors in this field have faced dual difficulties. As well as elucidating what are now believed to be the true mechanism of control, they were concomitantly required to dispel earlier, deeply rooted misconceptions. It has long been known that the red blood cell mass is designed almost exclusively for the purpose of transporting oxygen. Its functional capacity, then, must primarily be determined by the concentration of haemoglobin it maintains in the circulating blood.
thesis.creator: Gold, Phil.
thesis.subject: Physiology.
thesis.title: The interaction between ambient and tissue oxygen tensions and erythropoiesis.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The background of India comprises a long and chequered history which, from the prehistorical civilization of the Indus Valley to this date, covers a span of about six thousand years. In the early years of her history, India was a meeting place of different races. With the synthesis of the two main races, the Aryans and the Dravidians, a powerful Hindu civilization and culture were established. Because of its unique continuity and power of assimilation, this civilization forms the main basis of Indian culture. The major achievements of India in ancient times have been in fields such as philosophy, sciences, arts, architecture and sculpture.
thesis.creator: Gokhale, Sunanda. N.
thesis.subject: Education.
thesis.title: Language problem in education in India.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Attention was focussed, in 1949, on the Nuclear Shell Model (12) (14) when it succeeded in correlating diversified experimental facts, rather neatly in some cases, and in making definite predictions, many of which were subsequently verified. The scope and importance of the Theory of the Shell Structure have since increased greatly due to the simplicity of its basic assumptions and flexibility for empiricism. These have resulted in increasing areas of success and consequent remoulding of the theory.
thesis.creator: Ghosh, Amal. C.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: Search for new isomers in yttrium, niobium, antimony and iodine.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The installation of large blocks of induction motors over the last twenty years resulted in various induction motor representations in connection with stability studies. In most cases, however, induction motors make up less than half of the total connected load when more than one power station provides energy to the network. When the natural resources of remote areas in North America and on other continents are developed it seems likely that for some time to come most of these areas will be supplied by local power stations through radial lines rather than by network interconnections.
thesis.creator: Gevay, Bela. J.
thesis.subject: Electrical Engineering.
thesis.title: Transient stability of a network with large induction motor load.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Off-flavour development in raw or underblanched vegetables occurring as a result of an imbalance in the enzyme reactions was recognized early in the development of the frozen vegetable industry by Joslyn (1930), Tressler (1932) and Diehl and Berry (1933). Since then, numerous investigations have been carried out on various aspects of this problem but the reactions involved are still largely unknown. The investigators seem to agree that off-flavours are due to an enzymatic process because they do not develop in properly blanched vegetables.
thesis.creator: Fuleki, Tibor.
thesis.subject: Horticulture.
thesis.title: Acetaldehyde and alcohol production in frozen snap beans and their relation to off-flavour formation.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: It is axiomatic that taken together the works of Geoffrey Chaucer (1343? -- 1400) constitute the first sustained effort toward realism in fictional characterization found in English literature. This thesis examines the process whereby realism evolved in Chaucer's work and particularly the stylistic devices by which it was secured. In order better to understand Chaucer's contribution, we may briefly outline the obvious standards by which realm in characterization has come to be judged since his time.
thesis.creator: Friend, Myrna. M.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: Techniques of characterization in Chaucer.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The purpose of the work reported was to investigate the suitability of whale meat, whale liver, cod-fish products and of a dry meal mixture for the formulation of a mink ration. Until required for feeding, all the marine products were stored frozen. Chemical examinations of the frozen feeds for keeping quality over a prolonged period of time, demonstrated that storage conditions were adequate and that the levels of vitamin E remained remarkably constant.
thesis.creator: Friend, Douglas. W.
thesis.subject: Nutrition.
thesis.title: Studies on the suitability of some Newfoundland marine products in mink nutrition.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The research to be reported was concerned with the patterns of values among college women in a Canadian university. Through the study of a matched sample of freshmen and seniors, three interrelated problems were investigated: age differences in patterns of values, differences between usual and ideal patterns of values, and the relationships between patterns of values and behaviour. A study of the relevant literature reveals the patterns of values do charge during the four years of college, as well as after the college years, and that differences between usual and ideal patterns of values have been reported.
thesis.creator: Fitz-Gerald, Frances. L.
thesis.subject: Psychology.
thesis.title: Patterns of values among college women.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Investigation in 1953 (M.Sc. thesis) showed that fertilization with 76 pounds of nitrogen and 72 pounds of phosphate per acre, in addition to a maintenance application of 600 pounds of a 4-12-6 fertilizer, increased the nitrogen and phosphorus percentages in the corn leaf at the flowering stage. The levels of these leaf constituents and the yields at harvest were closely correlated, confirming the idea that chemical analysis of the plant at this stage of growth was a useful diagnostic tool. It was also shown that nitrogen, rather than phosphorus, was a major factor in modifying these plant characteristics.
thesis.creator: Findlay, Wallace. I.
thesis.subject: Agronomy.
thesis.title: Investigation of the effects of fertilization with nitrogen and phosphorous on the yield and composition of the corn plant.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.
